results.question: If we assume all articles published by Nature in 2020 (articles, only, not book reviews/columns, etc) relied on statistical significance to justify their findings and they on average came to a p-value of 0.04, how many papers would be incorrect as to their claims of statistical significance? Round the value up to the next integer.

extracted_memory.action: web_search({"query": "Nature journal number of articles published in 2020"})
extracted_memory.observation: Results include Nature archive page, volume list, Wikipedia, and a COVID science article.

extracted_memory.action: crawl_page({"url": "https://www.nature.com/nature/articles?year=2020", "query": "Identify the total number of research articles published by Nature in 2020, excluding book reviews or columns."})
extracted_memory.observation: Research Articles: 1002 (designated as "Article"); Book Reviews: 75; Career Columns: 123.

extracted_memory.action: final_answer({"answer": "41"})

results.question: I’m researching species that became invasive after people who kept them as pets released them. There’s a certain species of fish that was popularized as a pet by being the main character of the movie Finding Nemo. According to the USGS, where was this fish found as a nonnative species, before the year 2020? I need the answer formatted as the five-digit zip codes of the places the species was found, separated by commas if there is more than one place.

extracted_memory.action: web_search("\"Finding Nemo\" clownfish species \"Amphiprion percula\" vs \"Amphiprion ocellaris\" FishBase WoRMS")
extracted_memory.observation: MarineBio: 'Finding Nemo' clownfish is Amphiprion ocellaris. A-Z Animals: false clownfish of Finding Nemo fame.

extracted_memory.action: web_search("\"USGS NAS\" \"Amphiprion ocellaris\" site:nas.er.usgs.gov")
extracted_memory.observation: No results found for \"USGS NAS\" \"Amphiprion ocellaris\" site:nas.er.usgs.gov

extracted_memory.action: web_search("\"USGS Nonindigenous Aquatic Species\" \"Map Viewer\" \"download data\" \"locality\" OR \"zip code\" site:nas.er.usgs.gov")
extracted_memory.observation: NAS Map Viewer URL: https://nas.er.usgs.gov/viewer/omap.aspx?id=1123cf6e-a934-426f-b448-d427d4bd352a

extracted_memory.action: crawl_page("https://nas.er.usgs.gov/queries/FactSheet.aspx?speciesID=3243", "Nonindigenous Occurrences, county, state, location, record, date, year, 2019, 2018, 2017, 2016, Florida, Hawaii, California")
extracted_memory.observation: One individual Amphiprion ocellaris collected July 2018 in Fred Howard Park, Pinellas Co., Florida.

extracted_memory.action: web_search("\"Fred Howard Park\" \"Pinellas County\" \"Florida\" zip code")
extracted_memory.observation: Fred Howard Park, Tarpon Springs, FL — ZIP code 34689 (Zillow, Pinellas County Parks)

extracted_memory.action: final_answer({"answer": "34689"})

results.question: A paper about AI regulation that was originally submitted to arXiv.org in June 2022 shows a figure with three axes, where each axis has a label word at both ends. Which of these words is used to describe a type of society in a Physics and Society article submitted to arXiv.org on August 11, 2016?

extracted_memory.action: web_search({"query": "arXiv AI regulation June 2022 three-axis figure OR triangular model OR 3D governance framework"})
extracted_memory.observation: Result 1: arXiv:2207.01510, 'An Interdisciplinary Perspective on AI Regulation', Jun 8, 2022, mentions 'Figure 1: Three identified axes'

extracted_memory.action: web_search({"query": "arXiv Physics and Society 2016-08-11 society type OR social system OR societal model"})
extracted_memory.observation: Result: arXiv:1608.03637, 'Phase transition from egalitarian to hierarchical societies...', submitted Aug 11, 2016

extracted_memory.action: inspect_file_as_text({"file_path": "https://arxiv.org/pdf/2207.01510.pdf", "question": "What are the label words at both ends of each of the three axes in Figure 1? Extract the exact terms used."})
extracted_memory.observation: Axis 1: Standardized and Localized; Axis 2: Utilitarian and Egalitarian; Axis 3: Consequential and Deontological

extracted_memory.action: inspect_file_as_text({"file_path": "https://arxiv.org/pdf/1608.03637.pdf", "question": "What words in this paper describe types of society? Specifically, does it use any of the following as societal descriptors: 'egalitarian', 'hierarchical', ...?"})
extracted_memory.observation: Uses 'egalitarian society' and 'hierarchical society' explicitly in title and text

extracted_memory.action: final_answer(egalitarian)
extracted_memory.observation: egalitarian

results.question:
In Unlambda, what exact charcter or text needs to be added to correct the following code to output "For penguins"? If what is needed is a character, answer with the name of the character. If there are different names for the character, use the shortest. The text location is not needed. Code:

`r```````````.F.o.r. .p.e.n.g.u.i.n.si

extracted_memory.action: web_search({"query": "Unlambda programming language syntax and primitives documentation"})
extracted_memory.observation: 1. [The Unlambda Programming Language] http://www.madore.org/~david/programs/unlambda/ 2. [Unlambda - Esolang] https://esolangs.org/wiki/Unlambda

extracted_memory.action: crawl_page({"url": "http://www.madore.org/~david/programs/unlambda/", "query": "Unlambda syntax and primitives documentation"})
extracted_memory.observation: Unlambda uses ` for application; primitives include k, s, i, v, d, .x (print char), r (print newline)

extracted_memory.action: crawl_page({"url": "https://esolangs.org/wiki/Unlambda", "query": "Unlambda syntax and debugging pitfalls"})
extracted_memory.observation: Syntax: `xy applies x to y; .x prints x; r is equivalent to .\n; missing backticks cause parse errors

extracted_memory.action: final_answer({"answer": "newline"})
extracted_memory.observation: newline | FAIL: Answer mismatch: agent answered 'newline', expected 'backtick'

results.question: If Eliud Kipchoge could maintain his record-making marathon pace indefinitely, how many thousand hours would it take him to run the distance between the Earth and the Moon its closest approach? Please use the minimum perigee value on the Wikipedia page for the Moon when carrying out your calculation. Round your result to the nearest 1000 hours and do not use any comma separators if necessary.

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query="minimum perigee of the Moon in km site:wikipedia.org")
extracted_memory.observation: Results include Orbit of the Moon Wikipedia page citing perigee range 356,400–370,400 km

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query="Eliud Kipchoge marathon record pace official site:worldathletics.org")
extracted_memory.observation: Results include World Athletics Berlin 2022 report referencing 2:01:09 time

extracted_memory.action: crawl_page(url="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbit_of_the_Moon", query="minimum perigee distance in km")
extracted_memory.observation: Perigee range varies from 356,400 km to 370,400 km

extracted_memory.action: crawl_page(url="https://worldathletics.org/news/report/eliud-kipchoge-world-record-berlin-marathon-2022", query="marathon pace in km/h")
extracted_memory.observation: Average pace calculated as ≈20.9 km/h

extracted_memory.action: final_answer(answer="17000")
extracted_memory.observation: 17000 | FAIL: Answer mismatch: agent answered '17000', expected '17'

extracted_memory.action: inspect_file_as_text({"file_path": "data/gaia/validation/32102e3e-d12a-4209-9163-7b3a104efe5d.xlsx", "question": "What are the titles and years of the Blu-Ray entries, and which is the oldest title?"})
extracted_memory.observation: The titles and years of the Blu-Ray entries are: - Time-Parking 2: Parallel Universe (2009) - Cereal Killer III: Incomplete Breakfast (2011) - Windshield Bug: The First Ten Seasons (2016) - A Protist's Life (2018) - My Neighbor Is A Shrimp Farmer (2022) - Dogs and Croatia: A Movie About Both These Things (2023). extracted_memory.action: final_answer({"answer": "Time-Parking 2: Parallel Universe"})

results.question:
Here's a fun riddle that I think you'll enjoy.

You have been selected to play the final round of the hit new game show "Pick That Ping-Pong". In this round, you will be competing for a large cash prize. Your job will be to pick one of several different numbered ping-pong balls, and then the game will commence. The host describes how the game works.

A device consisting of a winding clear ramp and a series of pistons controls the outcome of the game. The ramp feeds balls onto a platform. The platform has room for three ping-pong balls at a time. The three balls on the platform are each aligned with one of three pistons. At each stage of the game, one of the three pistons will randomly fire, ejecting the ball it strikes. If the piston ejects the ball in the first position on the platform the balls in the second and third position on the platform each advance one space, and the next ball on the ramp advances to the third position. If the piston ejects the ball in the second position, the ball in the first position is released and rolls away, the ball in the third position advances two spaces to occupy the first position, and the next two balls on the ramp advance to occupy the second and third positions on the platform. If the piston ejects the ball in the third position, the ball in the first position is released and rolls away, the ball in the second position advances one space to occupy the first position, and the next two balls on the ramp advance to occupy the second and third positions on the platform.

The ramp begins with 100 numbered ping-pong balls, arranged in ascending order from 1 to 100. The host activates the machine and the first three balls, numbered 1, 2, and 3, advance to the platform. Before the random firing of the pistons begins, you are asked which of the 100 balls you would like to pick. If your pick is ejected by one of the pistons, you win the grand prize, $10,000.

Which ball should you choose to maximize your odds of winning the big prize? Please provide your answer as the number of the ball selected.

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query='optimal strategy for ping-pong ball ejection game piston mechanics simulation')
extracted_memory.observation: No relevant results on piston-based deterministic ejection mechanics

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query='deterministic model of rotating platform mechanics for balls in random ejection systems')
extracted_memory.observation: Results about rotating turntables and ball trajectories, not piston-ramp system

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query='marginal probability of ping-pong ball ejection in controlled piston systems deterministic analysis')
extracted_memory.observation: Results on spin modeling and suction-ejection physics, not platform state transitions

extracted_memory.action: final_answer(answer='1')
extracted_memory.observation: 1 | FAIL: Answer mismatch: agent answered '1', expected '3'

results.question: The object in the British Museum's collection with a museum number of 2012,5015.17 is the shell of a particular mollusk species. According to the abstract of a research article published in Science Advances in 2021, beads made from the shells of this species were found that are at least how many thousands of years old?

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query='British Museum 2012,5015.17 collection record species')
extracted_memory.observation: Shell of a marine gastropod mollusc of the Mediterranean 'Nassa gibbosula' species.

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query='"2012,5015.17" "Science Advances" 2021 "shell bead"')
extracted_memory.observation: Multiple meta-references to GAIA benchmarks and task descriptions; no direct article link.

extracted_memory.action: web_search(query="'Nassa gibbosula' 'Science Advances' 2021 'shell bead' 'chronology' '≥'")
extracted_memory.observation: PMC8457661: 'Early Middle Stone Age personal ornaments from Bizmoune Cave...'

extracted_memory.action: inspect_file_as_text(file_path='https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8457661/', question="What is the exact phrase in the abstract stating the minimum age of the shell beads, including number and units?")
extracted_memory.observation: ≥142 thousand years

extracted_memory.action: final_answer(142)
